text.div:
• Include these codes as defined in https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes
    CodeDisplayDefinition
    EmCare.B14S2.DE07generalised skin problemThe client has a generalised skin problem
    EmCare.B14S2.DE08localised skin problemThe client has a localised skin problem
    EmCare.B14S2.DE09no problemThe client does not have a generalised or localised skin problem
    EmCare.B14S2.DE18papular urticaria or papular pruritic eruptionsThe client has Papular Urticaria or Papular Pruritic Eruptions • Itchy papules at different stages of evolution. • Found on the arms and legs. • Healed lesions are often dark/ hyperpigmented. • The itch is difficult to manage. • Essential to exclude scabies.
    EmCare.B14S2.DE19ringworm (tinea)The client has Ringworm (Tinea) - • An itchy circular lesion with a raised edge and fine scaly area. • Scalp lesions may result in loss of hair
    EmCare.B14S2.DE21scabiesThe client has Scabies - • Intense itching, more severe at night. • Small burrows between fingers, tows, elbow areas and buttocks. • Secondary infection may occur. • Small babies may have vesicles and pustules on the palms and soles and face. • The infestation spreads easily, usually affecting more than one person in the household
    EmCare.B14S2.DE22chickenpoxThe client has Chickenpox - Mild fever preceding the rash. • Rash begins on the trunk and face, later spreads to the arms and legs. • Vesicles appear progressively over days and forms scabs after they rupture. • Contagious from the fever starts until all lesions have crusted. • Usually lasts for about 1 week.
    EmCare.B14S2.DE23herpes zosterThe client has Herpes Zoster - Vesicles in one area on one side of body with intense pain or scars plus shooting pain. • They are uncommon in children except when they are immune-compromised
    EmCare.B14S2.DE25impetigoThe client has Impetigo- Pustules and papules with honey -coloured crusts. • Commonly starts on the face or buttocks, then spreads to the neck, hands, arms and legs.
    EmCare.B14S2.DE31molluscum contagiosumThe client has Molluscum Contagiosum -Caused by a poxvirus. • Dome-shaped papules with a central depression (umblication). • Most commonly seen on the face and trunk in children
    EmCare.B14S2.DE32wartsThe client has Warts - Appears as papules or nodules with a rough surface. • Seen most often on the hands and fingers, but can be found anywhere on the body.
    EmCare.B14S2.DE33seborrhoeic dermatitisThe client has Seborrhoeic Dermatitis - Greasy scales and redness on central face, body folds. • The scalp, face, ears and skin folds (e.g. axillae, groins, under the breasts) are commonly affected.
    EmCare.B14S2.DE35fixed drug reactionThe client has Fixed Drug Reaction - One or more dark round or oval skin lesions with central vesicles . • The lesions recur on the same spot, and increase in number with each successive attack
    EmCare.B14S2.DE36eczemaThe client has Eczema - Erythematous (red), sometimes scaly plaques found on the face, flexures, trunk and extensors. • Yellow pustules which crust indicate secondary bacterial infection.
    EmCare.B14S2.DE37steven johnson syndrome (sjs)The client has Steven Johnson Syndrome (SJS) - Severe and acute reaction due to many drugs, the commonest being cotrimoxazole or nevirapine. • Lesions involve the skin as well as the mucous membranes (e.g. eyes, mouth and genitalia). • May start as widespread red irregular rash with or without blisters. The blisters rupture leaving denuded areas of skin. • May cause difficulty in breathing.
    EmCare.B14S2.DE44skin problemThe health care worker would like to add a skin problem
    EmCare.B14S2.DE45oral sores or mouth ulcersThe health care worker would like to add an Oral Sores or Mouth Ulcers problem
    EmCare.B14S2.DE46eye problemThe health care worker would like to add an Eye problem
    EmCare.B14S2.DE47no - do not add a skin or mouth or eye problemThe healthcare worker would not like to add a Skin or Mouth or Eye Problem
    EmCare.B21S2.DE29no breastmilk at allThe caregiver does not give the client any breastmilk at all
    EmCare.B21S2.DE11inappropriate replacement milkThe care giver is giving inappropriate replacement milk
    EmCare.B21S2.DE10appropriate replacement milkThe care giver is giving appropriate replacement milk
    EmCare.B22.DE18chest indrawing (post inhaled bronchodilator trial)
    EmCare.B22.DE19respiratory rate (post inhaled bronchodilator trial)
    EmCare.B22.DE20fast breathing (post inhaled bronchodilator trial)
    EmCare.B22.DE21no fast breathing and no chest indrawing (post inhaled bronchodilator trial)The client has no fast breathing and no chest indrawing
    EmCare.B22.DE22inhaled bronchodilator trial not feasible or available

name: valueset-emcareobservationvalueset
description: Codes representing possible values for the Provide an estimated age or estimated date of birth element

designation.value: The client has a generalised skin problem
The client has a localised skin problem
The client does not have a generalised or localised skin problem

concept.display: papular urticaria or papular pruritic eruptions

designation.value:
The client has Papular Urticaria or Papular Pruritic Eruptions 
• Itchy papules at different stages of evolution.
• Found on the arms and legs.
• Healed lesions are often dark/ hyperpigmented.
• The itch is difficult to manage.
• Essential to exclude scabies.

The client has Ringworm (Tinea) - 
• An itchy circular lesion with a raised edge and fine scaly area.
• Scalp lesions may result in loss of hair

The client has Scabies -
• Intense itching, more severe at night.
• Small burrows between fingers, tows, elbow areas and buttocks.
• Secondary infection may occur.
• Small babies may have vesicles and pustules on the palms and soles and face.
• The infestation spreads easily, usually affecting more than one person in the household

The client has Chickenpox - Mild fever preceding the rash.
• Rash begins on the trunk and face,
later spreads to the arms and legs.
• Vesicles appear progressively over days and forms scabs
after they rupture.
• Contagious from the fever starts until all lesions have
crusted.
• Usually lasts for about 1 week.

The client has Herpes Zoster -  Vesicles in one area on one side of body with intense pain or scars plus shooting pain.
• They are uncommon in children except when they are immune-compromised

The client has Impetigo- Pustules and papules with honey -coloured crusts.
• Commonly starts on the face or buttocks, then spreads to the neck, hands, arms and legs.

The client has Molluscum Contagiosum -Caused by a poxvirus.
• Dome-shaped papules with a central depression
(umblication).
• Most commonly seen on the face and trunk in children

The client has Warts - Appears as papules or nodules with a rough surface.
• Seen most often on the hands and fingers, but can be
found anywhere on
the body.

The client has Seborrhoeic Dermatitis - Greasy scales and redness on central face, body folds.
• The scalp, face, ears and skin folds (e.g. axillae, groins, under the breasts) are commonly affected.

The client has Fixed Drug Reaction - One or more dark round or oval skin lesions with central vesicles .
• The lesions recur on the same spot, and increase in number with each successive attack

The client has Eczema - Erythematous (red), sometimes scaly plaques found on the face, flexures, trunk and extensors.
• Yellow pustules which crust indicate
secondary bacterial infection.

The client has Steven Johnson Syndrome (SJS) - Severe and acute reaction due to many drugs, the commonest being cotrimoxazole or nevirapine.
• Lesions involve the skin as well as the mucous membranes (e.g. eyes, mouth and genitalia).
• May start as widespread red irregular rash with or without blisters. The blisters rupture leaving denuded areas of skin.
• May cause difficulty in breathing.
The health care worker would like to add a skin problem
The health care worker would like to add an Oral Sores or Mouth Ulcers problem
The health care worker would like to add an Eye problem

concept.display: no - do not add a skin or mouth or eye problem

designation.value: The healthcare worker would not like to add a Skin or Mouth or Eye Problem
The caregiver does not give the client any breastmilk at all

The care giver is giving appropriate  replacement milk

concept.display: no fast breathing and no chest indrawing (post inhaled bronchodilator trial)
inhaled bronchodilator trial not feasible or available
